author: By Michael Paterniti
title: Seeking Enlightenment, He Disappeared Into a Hiker’s Bermuda Triangle

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Brian Laundrie Claimed Responsibility for Gabrielle Petito’s Death, F.B.I. Says
description: The agency, closing a high-profile case, said that a notebook found near Mr. Laundrie’s body included statements in which he confessed to killing his fiancée.
content: Brian Laundrie claimed responsibility for killing his fiancée, Gabrielle Petito, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said on Friday, as it prepared to close a case that had galvanized social media and prompted widespread sleuthing by amateur detectives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How Much Stock Is Too Much in Retirement?
description: Stocks and bonds are core investments. Now, Vanguard is suggesting that retirees willing and able to bear the risk may want a stock target of 50 percent.
content: The stock market can provide eye-popping returns but can also be counted on to produce big losses. High-quality bonds, on the other hand, typically generate modest returns but are better for income and relative stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Will Climate Action Happen Now?
description: More Democrats are focusing on it.
content: Politicians, journalists and activists all like to use the phrase “last, best chance” when talking about the climate. As in: The Glasgow climate conference is the world’s last, best chance to avoid terrible climate destruction. Or: The U.S. now faces its last, best chance to address the climate crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: You Quit. I Quit. We All Quit. And It’s Not a Coincidence.
description: Why the decision to leave a job can become contagious.
content: Something infectious is spreading through the work force. Its symptoms present in a spate of two-week notices. Its transmission is visible in real time. And few bosses seem to know how to inoculate their staff against this quitagion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Republicans Think There Is a ‘Takeover’ Happening. They Have Some Reading to Do.
description: Conservatives can’t pick and choose which parts of the Constitution they like.
content: Much of what’s in the Constitution is vague, imprecise or downright unclear. But some parts are very straightforward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: For Nadal and His Contemporaries, It Is About Winning, and Quickly
description: Dropping only one set in the first week of the Australian Open gave the 20-time Grand Slam champion, at age 35, energy for later in the tournament. Aging tennis stars, take note.
content: Rafael Nadal knew something had to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: Suspect Charged in Taiwan’s Deadly ‘Ghost Building’ Fire
description: Prosecutors say the suspect, seeking revenge on her partner after a quarrel, poured hot ashes on a sofa. The resulting fire killed 46 people.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Taiwanese prosecutors on Friday formally charged a suspect with homicide and arson in the case of an October fire that killed 46 and injured dozens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Court Battle Over a Ventilator Takes a Patient From Minnesota to Texas
description: Scott Quiner, who was unvaccinated and hospitalized with Covid-19, had been on a ventilator for weeks when doctors told his wife they would be taking him off the machine.
content: Scott Quiner, an operations manager at a transportation company in Minnesota, became sick with Covid-19 in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: How Much Are You Willing to Pay for a Burrito?
description: The pandemic has led to the largest price spikes at fast-food restaurants in two decades.
content: On a chilly Tuesday afternoon this month, James Marsh stopped by a Chipotle near his suburban Chicago home to grab something to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Consider Limits of Ruling for Native Americans in Oklahoma
description: But the justices rejected a request from state officials to revisit a 2020 ruling that much of eastern Oklahoma falls within an Indian reservation.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide a question left open by its landmark 2020 decision declaring that much of eastern Oklahoma falls within an Indian reservation. But the justices rejected a request to consider overruling the decision entirely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: One Opera Opening Would Make Any Composer Happy. He Has Two.
description: Ricky Ian Gordon’s “Intimate Apparel” and “The Garden of the Finzi-Continis” are premiering in New York almost simultaneously.
content: When the composer Ricky Ian Gordon saw Stephen Sondheim’s “Follies” on Broadway in the early 1970s, it was unlike anything he’d watched on a stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: ‘Addressless’ Is on the Streets and in Your Home
description: This hybrid of theater and game asks us to consider homelessness empathetically but can’t overcome the friction between education and entertainment.
content: In June, after a series of court battles, 60-some men were moved out of the Lucerne, an Upper West Side hotel that had served as a shelter during the first year of the pandemic. Their presence had divided the neighborhood, with some residents starting a Facebook group to complain about how the men had decreased their quality of life, even as there was no discernible uptick in the local crime rate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Honey, I Shrank the Economy’s Capacity
description: Why the trend has not been our friend.
content: Back in 2010 a group of conservative academics, economists and money managers signed an open letter warning that the efforts of the Federal Reserve to support the economy would be dangerously inflationary. But the inflation never came. So four years later Bloomberg reached out to as many of the signatories as they could, to ask what happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: When Pandemic Stars’ Shines Dim
description: Shares in Netflix and Peloton soared in the early part of the pandemic. Now they’re tumbling.
content: The future path of the pandemic is uncertain, but investors may have already made up their minds about the prospects for companies that had prospered months earlier. Netflix and Peloton plunged late in the day yesterday, on signs that “stay at home” stocks, which were already under pressure, could take a turn for the worse as people begin to venture out again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal, Rachel Quester, Michael Simon Johnson, Eric Krupke, Austin Mitchell, Robert Jimison, Liz O. Baylen, Brad Fisher, Marion Lozano and Dan Powell
title: What the ‘Djokovic Affair’ Revealed About Australia
description: On the surface, it looked like a controversy over athletes and vaccines. But for Australians, the decision to deport Novak Djokovic became about something different.
content: Novak Djokovic, the world No. 1 player in men’s tennis, had a lot at stake going into this year’s Australian Open. If he were to win, the Grand Slam would be his 21st, making him the most decorated male tennis player in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: United by Sorrow, They Forged a Joyful Future
description: Christina Vance and Greg Winick met in 2010, when they worked together for a few weeks. Years later, after each had suffered hardship, they reconnected and started to build a relationship.
content: Christina Vance and Greg Winick dressed up as superheroes for their first date at a 2017 Halloween party in Totowa, N.J. She went as Batgirl, he as Batman. A good pair for couples, the costumes also alluded to the strength and resilience that brought each to that moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: IBM is selling off Watson Health to a private equity firm.
description: The sale is part of IBM’s effort to tighten the focus of its business and shed operations.
content: IBM is selling its Watson Health data and analytics business, the final step in the company’s retreat from what it once called a “moonshot” venture to improve health care, helping save lives and trim medical costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: A W.H.O. panel recommends extending the Pfizer vaccine to children 5 to 11.
description: Advisers endorsed the wider use of vaccines for children and boosters for high-risk people, bringing its guidance closer to that of most wealthy nations.
content: The World Health Organization, which has been resistant to endorse the wide use of booster shots and slow in recommending vaccinations for children, moved on Friday to revise its advice on both fronts, bringing its guidance closer to that of most wealthy nations, including the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: UConn Owes Former Coach Kevin Ollie $11 Million, Arbitrator Rules
description: The ruling, which the University of Connecticut disagreed with, came in response to a grievance filed by Ollie when he was fired in 2018.
content: The University of Connecticut must pay a former men’s basketball coach, Kevin Ollie, more than $11 million in the next 10 business days for improperly firing him, an arbitrator ruled on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: epiphany
description: This word has appeared in 109 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking McConnell’s Comparison of Black Turnout Rates
description: The Republican leader’s claim about high voter turnout in previous elections wasn’t too far off base, but that doesn’t mean voting access is assured.
content: Hours before a failed effort by Democrats to pass a voting rights bill in the Senate, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky was asked in a news conference on Wednesday for his message to voters worried about access to the polls during the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebekah Peppler
title: A French 75 for Everyone
description: Thanks to a deeply flavored citrus shrub, this classic cocktail can be adapted for those who are drinking, want something lighter, or who are fully abstaining from alcohol.
content: A drink doesn’t have to be booze-forward, or make you tipsy after just one, to be cocktail-hour appropriate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Republicans Want New Tool in Elusive Search for Voter Fraud: Election Police
description: Republicans in three states have proposed strike forces against election crimes even though fraud cases remain minuscule.
content: WASHINGTON — Reprising the rigged-election belief that has become a mantra among their supporters, Republican politicians in at least three states are proposing to establish police forces to hunt exclusively for voter fraud and other election crimes, a category of offenses that experts say is tiny at best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harry Litman
title: Will Madison Cawthorn Be Brought Down by ‘Insurrection’?
description: Why a section of the 14th Amendment could offer a challenge to some Republicans running for the House this year.
content: Representative Madison Cawthorn has breezily dismissed a candidacy challenge filed by voters in his home state, North Carolina, seeking to bar him from re-election to the House of Representatives based on his role in the events of Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What a Dry January Means for California’s Drought
description: Low levels of precipitation in what is usually a rainy month are dashing hopes of reversing the drought in 2022.
content: In the final three months of 2021, hope arrived in California in the form of rain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: China Holds the Line on ‘Zero Covid,’ but Some Wonder for How Long
description: More people are being caught up in the country’s virus-control dragnet. Some think the no-tolerance policy is unsustainable.
content: In a glitzy Shanghai shopping district, about 40 people who happened to be at a Uniqlo store were informed that they would be spending the night there. A suspected Covid case had been traced to the shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Workers at an Activision game studio say they are forming a union.
description: The Game Workers Alliance represents workers at Raven Software, a studio owned by Activision Blizzard where some employees walked out in early December to protest work conditions.
content: A group of workers at Raven Software, a studio owned by Activision Blizzard, said Friday that they were forming a union and wanted the prominent video game company to voluntarily recognize it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj
title: Oil Spill Triggered by Tsunami Devastates Coast of Peru
description: Initially said to be seven barrels, the oil spill turned out to be 6,000, the environment ministry said, and has led Peru to call for international aid.
content: The Peruvian government has asked for international support in responding to an oil spill off the coast of Lima that it called the city’s “worst ecological disaster” in recent history, as crude continued to wash onto beaches nearly a week after waves triggered by Tonga’s volcano eruption disrupted operations at a local refinery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: With Broad Safety Net Bill Stalled, Democrats Weigh What to Salvage
description: As discussions resumed over how to whittle down the plan, Senator Joe Manchin, a key holdout, said any talks would be starting with “a clean sheet of paper.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s concession this week that his marquee social safety net and climate package must be broken apart to have any hope of becoming law reignited a debate among Democrats over which pieces of the plan to prioritize as they work to salvage it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: When Rules Aren’t Just Rules
description: What the Djokovic affair reveals about global border policing.
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Dickson
title: Augmented Reality Theater Takes a Bow. In Your Kitchen.
description: The Immersive Storytelling Studio at the National Theater in London is using technology to bring a miniature musical to viewers’ homes. It’s one of several high-tech British projects pushing dramatic boundaries.
content: LONDON — Standing in front of a golden bandstand, dressed in a white satin gown and pearls, the vocalist Nubiya Brandon sashayed to a gentle beat. Stepping toward the spotlight, she took a lazy turn around the stage, singing a playful calypso number and smiling occasionally at the band behind.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Chinese Language Revolution
description: Jing Tsu talks about “Kingdom of Characters,” and Kathryn Schulz discusses “Lost and Found.”
content: Jing Tsu’s new book, “Kingdom of Characters,” is about the long and concerted efforts made by  linguists, activists and others to adapt Chinese writing to the modern world, so that it could be used in everything from typewriters and telegraphs to artificial intelligence and automation. On this week’s podcast, Tsu talks about that revolution, from its roots to the present day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike and Madeleine Ngo
title: Anti-Abortion Marchers Gather With an Eye on the Supreme Court
description: The annual March for Life rally is taking on a celebratory tone this year as participants expect the Supreme Court to overturn Roe v. Wade.
content: Anti-abortion protesters descended on Washington from across the country on Friday for the annual March for Life, a ritual that this year took on a tone of hopeful celebration as they anticipated the Supreme Court overturning the decision that established a constitutional right to abortion half a century ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Kate Conger
title: Twitter shakes up its security team.
description: Parag Agrawal, the new chief executive, fired the company’s head of security this week. Twitter’s chief information security officer is also leaving.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter shook up the top ranks of its security team this week with the termination of the head of security and the exit of the chief information security officer, the company told employees on Wednesday, as its new chief executive reorganizes the social media service.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Where Can I Find the Perfect Pair of Black Pants?
description: A reader seeks advice on shopping for a wardrobe staple.
content: The perfect pair of black pants is, like the perfect white T-shirt, one of fashion’s holy grails. It floats, seemingly just out of reach in our imaginations, the answer to all our wardrobe ills if only we could find them.

description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

title: Tongan Man Swept Away by Tsunami Survived After 26 Hours Afloat
description: Lisala Folau, a retired carpenter, spent a night and day at sea after an undersea volcanic eruption sent waves crashing through his home on the island of Atata.
content: Lisala Folau had been at sea for about 12 hours, drifting between the islands of Tonga overnight after a tsunami hit his home, when he saw a police patrol boat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: The Fearsome, Quiet Champion
description: Francis Ngannou, known widely for his devastating punches, journeyed from Cameroon to France to the United States to become a mixed martial arts star. Yet his future in the U.F.C. is unclear.

description: If you’re interested in alien invasions, vivid dreamscapes or adorable cats, this collection of streaming picks may be just right for you.

author: By Liam Stack
title: Was Dorothy Day Too Left-Wing to Be a Catholic Saint?
description: The Archdiocese of New York has asked the Vatican to consider the social activist for sainthood. But church leaders are not entirely comfortable with her politics.
content: Hundreds of people gathered at St. Patrick’s Cathedral to celebrate an important moment for Catholics in New York. Cardinal Timothy Dolan delivered a homily on the life of one of their own, Dorothy Day, a native New Yorker and anarchist writer and activist who died in 1980.

title: Two Novelists, Avi and Brian Farrey, Use Fiction to Show Kids Why Facts Matter

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: Corey Stoll on Becoming the New Face of Fortune in ‘Billions’
description: The actor talked about taking over from Damian Lewis as the show’s chief nemesis, and why a do-gooder billionaire is still a billionaire.

title: André Leon Talley: Mentor in Chief
description: He was famous for his larger-than-life persona, but a lesser-known fact was that he took a select few under his wing and guided their careers.
content: “He was my first real mentor,” said Dario Calmese, a photographer and fashion consultant, referring to André Leon Talley, the former Vogue editor who died on Monday,
source.name: The New York Times

title: Their DNA Hides a Warning, but They Don’t Want to Know What It Says
description: Some volunteers for biobanks, which collect genetic information to study health across populations, have been surprised to be informed they carry risky mutations.
content: Marin Konstadt, visiting family in Florida, was at the opera in 2020 when she got a call on her cellphone. She called back at intermission. The caller, a genetics specialist at a hospital, had some important news for her. She has a genetic variant that can increase her disease risk. Did she want to know more?
source.name: The New York Times

title: More Than 330,000 Pacifiers Recalled Over Choking Hazard
description: Mushie & Co, a baby goods store, announced a voluntary recall of its FRIGG pacifier after more than 200 reports that the pacifier’s silicone nipple detached from its base.
content: More than 330,000 pacifiers have been voluntarily recalled by their manufacturer after reports that they could pose a choking hazard, according to a notice posted by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission.

description: A rowdy movie house suddenly goes dark, inspiring an outpouring of dismay and reminiscences.
content: On a recent morning, the Regal UA Court Street in Brooklyn was uncharacteristically quiet. Posters for “Jackass Forever” and “American Underdog” hung in its windows, but the curving marquee had been stripped of its letters, and its glass doors were locked. Peering inside, you could see a scattering of dead leaves on the floor of the darkened lobby, like tumbleweeds in a western.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Intel to Invest at Least $20 Billion in New Chip Factories in Ohio
description: Building up U.S. chip production has been a focus of lawmakers and companies alike amid a global shortage of the crucial components.
content: Intel has selected Ohio for a new chip manufacturing complex that would cost at least $20 billion, ramping up an effort to increase U.S. production of computer chips as users grapple with a lingering shortage of the vital components.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: After a Marathon First Date, a Warp-Speed Romance
description: Within 30 days of their six-hour first date, Kimberly Chexnayder and Jason White had said “I love you” and moved in together. An engagement came soon after.
content: Kimberly Chexnayder, the N.F.L. host known as Kimmi Chex, had recently moved from New York to Los Angeles when her best friend Mario Williams texted her in May 2020 to say he had just encountered her future husband.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: They Love Coins (Just Not Bitcoin)
description: Is coin collecting cool again? Four millennial and Gen Z numismatists on why they collect: “They’re little art objects you can hold in your hand.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: Love Triangle Challenges Reign of Japan’s Monkey Queen
description: Yakei became a rare alpha female of a macaque troop in a nature reserve, but a kind of simian love triangle may endanger her grip on power.
content: Smashing the patriarchy in the human world has been easier said than done. But last year, a 9-year-old female Japanese macaque in a reserve in southern Japan showed humans how it’s done by violently overthrowing the alpha male of her troop to become its first female leader in the reserve’s 70-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: ‘As We See It’ Is Not a Typical Portrayal of Autism
description: Most autistic characters have been played onscreen by neurotypical actors. A new series bucks the trend, starring three leads who are on the spectrum.
content: In the new Amazon series “As We See It,” Violet, a 25-year-old cashier at Arby’s, desperately wants a boyfriend, but she is looking for love in all the wrong places (namely, Arby’s). Violet’s needs are simple. She wants someone cute, someone to go on fun dates with. Most of all, she wants someone normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: TotalEnergies and Chevron prepare to leave a critical gas field in Myanmar.
description: Amid deteriorating human rights, an oil giant finds it can no longer make a “sufficiently positive contribution in the country.”
content: TotalEnergies, the French oil giant, and Chevron said Friday that they would begin taking steps to withdraw from an offshore natural gas field in Myanmar that is a critical source of energy for both the host country and neighboring Thailand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Saudi-Led Airstrikes Kill Scores at a Prison in Yemen
description: The strikes, which also knocked out the country’s internet, came after Iran-backed Houthi rebels attacked the U.A.E., a key partner in the Saudi-led coalition that has been fighting in Yemen for years.
content: CAIRO — The seven-year-old war in Yemen intensified again on Friday when airstrikes by the Saudi-led military coalition on northern Yemen killed at least 70 people and knocked out the entire country’s internet, according to international aid groups and the rebels who control the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam and Blake Hounshell
title: Winning Virginia Was the Easy Part. Can Glenn Youngkin Govern?
description: The new governor is converting his education-centric campaign message into policy. Republicans are pleased. Democrats are skeptical.
content: Glenn Youngkin’s winning bid for governor of Virginia last year was closely scrutinized by both parties for signs of what was to come in 2022.

title: Hong Kong’s ‘zero-Covid’ policy hurts its service sector, and other Asia virus news.
description: For nearly two years, some businesses owners in Hong Kong felt confident that they had weathered the worst of the pandemic. That changed this month when Omicron started spreading, and officials returned to the trusted “zero-Covid” playbook that Hong Kong shares with mainland China.

description: The extra doses were most effective against infection and death among Americans aged 50 and older.
content: Booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines aren’t just preventing infections with the highly contagious Omicron variant — they’re also keeping infected Americans from ending up in the hospital, according to data published on Friday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Ann Arensberg, Insightful Novelist of Mysteries and Manners, Dies at 84
description: Her debut novel, “Sister Wolf,” won a 1981 National Book Award. Her later books explored the Manhattan theater scene and the New England occult.
content: Ann Arensberg, a novelist equally at home writing Gothic mysteries set in dark corners of New England and airy satires set in her native territory, the Manhattan publishing and cultural scene, died on Jan. 14 at a hospital in Sharon, Conn. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: The Markets Tremble as the Fed’s Lifeline Fades
description: Stocks are off to their worst start of a year since 2016 as the central bank pulls back the enormous stimulus programs it began in the early months of the pandemic.
content: After falling for a fourth day in a row on Friday, the stock market suffered its worst week in nearly two years, and so far in January the S&P 500 is off to its worst start since 2016. Technology stocks have been hit especially hard, with the Nasdaq Composite Index dropping more than 10 percent from its most recent high, which qualifies as a correction in Wall Street talk.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Broadway Producer Spends His Sundays
description: Theater may be struggling, but Ron Simons is committed to opening his next show, “For Colored Girls,” this spring.
content: Ron Simons, one of a handful of Black Broadway producers in New York, has won Tony Awards for “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love and Murder,” “Porgy & Bess,” “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike” and “Jitney.” Not to be outdone by the pandemic, he recently produced “Thoughts of a Colored Man,” which closed last month, and his next show, “For Colored Girls,” is scheduled to open this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Brian Cox Takes Stock of His Eventful Life on Stage and Screen
description: In “Putting the Rabbit in the Hat,” the actor currently thriving as Logan Roy in “Succession” recounts his Scottish upbringing, his years in the theater and his experiences in Hollywood.
content: I’m such a fan of the HBO series “Succession,” about a morally depraved, megarich media family, that I hum its theme song in the shower and have taken to wearing commanding pantsuits. So when I picked up “Putting the Rabbit in the Hat,” the new memoir by Brian Cox, who plays the family’s tyrannical patriarch, Logan Roy, I was desperate for tidbits to tide me over during the long wait for Season 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clarissa Wei
title: In Singapore, Lunar New Year Is a Multicultural Feast
description: The ethnic diversity of the island nation shines through food during the two-week festivities.
content: For about two decades, Shila Das has brought her chicken curry and nasi biryani to her best friend, Wendy Chua, for their Lunar New Year celebrations together in their native Singapore. They start the day with those dishes, then have hot pot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch a Seductive Moment in ‘The Power of the Dog’
description: Jane Campion narrates an intimate scene between Benedict Cumberbatch and Kodi Smit-McPhee.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alwa Cooper
title: In New Orleans, a White Picket Fence That’s Seen Better Days
description: Having come upon a broken-down partition on a walk, Willie Birch decided to paint what he saw: a fitting metaphor for his city and the country as a whole.
content: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a painting by Willie Birch, whose next show, at Fort Gansevoort Gallery in New York City, opens March 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: At 74, He Still Has an Innate Ability to Kill
description: Stephen Hunter’s new novel, “Targeted,” features the retired Marine sniper Bob Lee Swagger — who’s still a crack shot — in his 12th adventure.
content: Stephen Hunter sure does love to write about guns. That’s the main takeaway from TARGETED (Emily Bestler/Atria, 364 pp., $28.99), the 12th Bob Lee Swagger novel. Earlier volumes painted more three-dimensional portraits of the supporting players surrounding Swagger, the 74-year-old former Marine sniper with a bad hip and an innate ability to kill, but this book dispenses with nuance, except in loving descriptions of specific rifles, cartridges and bullets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: A Viral Photo Helps Bring Syrian Refugee Family to Italy
description: A Syrian family portrayed in an award-winning photo has come to Italy for treatment and better lives.
content: SIENA, Italy — The award-winning photograph — of a man who had lost a leg in a bomb attack in Syria, hoisting into the air his son, born without limbs, another casualty of the country’s civil war — went viral last year in Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren LeBlanc
title: From Blood and Phlegm to Alcohol and Defenestration, Novels of Heartache
description: Fiction by Mina Seçkin, Lisa Harding, Neel Patel and Renée Branum tells of transnational family and loss.
content: THE FOUR HUMORS By Mina Seçkin 353 pp. Catapult. $27.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: The Chief of CVS Health Wants to Be Part of People’s ‘Everyday Life’
description: Karen S. Lynch, who took over during the pandemic, is dealing with insurance, opioids, vaccines, politics and more.
content: Some corporations are so big, so intertwined with the economy and our daily lives and current events and politics, that it can be difficult to grasp the true scope of their importance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Patrick McGeehan
title: How Remote Work Is Devastating New York City’s Commuter Rails
description: Before the pandemic, they relied on office workers, who spent up to $500 a month on tickets. At the M.T.A., those sales are down 75 percent.
content: Before the coronavirus pandemic, more than a million workers commuted into New York City every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Why the Woman Who Dressed ‘The Gilded Age’ Is on the Verge of Giving Up
description: Helen Uffner has dressed Broadway, Hollywood and TV shows for more than 40 years. But high-rise developers and Amazon distribution centers are making it impossible to store her extraordinary vintage collection.
content: Helen Uffner began her love affair with old clothes as a young teenager, wandering into estate sales near her family’s home in Queens, unnerving her father, who had immigrated to this country as a Holocaust survivor and worried that people would think he could not afford to outfit his daughter properly. As a high school student in the mid-1960s, she would go to auction houses in Greenwich Village to buy vintage clothes and antique jewelry, using her babysitting earnings. With the prospect of a career in period fashion lacking promise, she sensibly joined a management consultancy after college. Soon enough the sexism got to her so she quit and decided to monetize her passion, drawing from the large collection she had already amassed which, at the time, focused on Victorian lingerie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: On Voting Rights, Democrats Say They Had to Go Down Swinging
description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, chose to plunge ahead because of the importance of the issue even after the outcome became preordained.
content: WASHINGTON — In forcing a tense Senate showdown over voting rights, Senator Chuck Schumer violated a cardinal rule of congressional leadership: Don’t go to the floor unless you are certain you have the votes to win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: How I Cut My Family’s Cable and Streaming Bill by $170
description: After I realized we were paying more than $400 a month, I knew I had to do something. Here’s what I learned.
content: It was another fat cable bill that finally spurred me to act. For my New Year’s resolution, I would cut the cord and watch streaming services instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Doors
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: Thich Nhat Hanh, Zen Master and Political Reformer, Dies at 95
description: A monk with global influence and an ally of Martin Luther King, he championed what he called “engaged Buddhism,” applying its principles in pressing for peace.
content: Thich Nhat Hanh, a Vietnamese Buddhist monk who was one of the world’s most influential Zen masters, spreading messages of mindfulness, compassion and nonviolence, died on Saturday at his home in the Tu Hieu Temple in Hue, Vietnam. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ireland Outraged by Teacher’s Murder
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 21, 2022.
content: “It’s not about being in the wrong place at the wrong time. As a woman you are just coming home from work, going out, living your life, and every moment can be your last.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Halpert
title: Vaccine Hesitancy Comes for Pet Parents
description: Some pet owners have extended vaccine worries to their furry pals. When is it appropriate to skip a dog or cat’s shot, and when is it absolutely crucial?
content: In the spring of 2020, Kelly Kerlin’s veterinarian gave her rescue dog, Finley, vaccinations against Lyme disease and leptospirosis, administering them behind the dog’s neck at the top of her back. Finley soon developed a lump slightly smaller than a golf ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Imani Perry
title: New Orleans Is a Place Where There Is Violence in the Sweetness, Horror in the Beauty
description: The city has been shaped by both suffering and celebration, and its strength lies in its dualities.
content: I’ve always felt connected to New Orleans through my mother. As a young adult, she spent several years at the Sisters of the Holy Family convent in New Orleans East. The order, which was founded in 1842 by Henriette Delille to provide a home for Black women with spiritual vocation, was only the second order of Black nuns in the country, and it is still around today. New Orleans shaped my mother — her cooking, her politics — and, in turn, it shaped me. Because my biological father was born to a native New Orleanian, I’ve always assumed that I might one day run into a long-lost cousin on its streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: A ‘High Priestess of Satanic Art’? This Organist Can Only Laugh.
description: For more than a decade, Anna von Hausswolff has been bringing the sound of pipe organs to rock fans. But Roman Catholic extremists have tried to stop her playing shows in churches.
content: When Anna von Hausswolff, an acclaimed Swedish songwriter and organist, first heard that a conservative Roman Catholic website was calling her a satanist and demanding a concert boycott, she and her team laughed it off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Samara Golden Is Spilling Her ‘Guts’
description: The Los Angeles artist has created an ambitious new installation full of inner turmoil.
content: LOS ANGELES — It’s a dizzying and disorienting experience, where moments of serenity jockey with sensations of disgust. Inaugurating Night Gallery’s new warehouse space, which opens this weekend, the artist Samara Golden has built a mirrored chamber that creates the illusion of a skyscraper. Different floors offer competing images — from calm turquoise waters to coiled snakes and crabs — capturing the emotional whiplash of the last two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Prepare for a steep ascent while solving Richard Silvestri’s tricky puns.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — This is a hearty, crunchy grid from one of our longtime regulars. Richard Silvestri has constructed 47 cryptic puzzles for The Times since 1997, and I’d bet that I’ve tried them all to evolving levels of success. Twenty years ago I used to give up, but nowadays I build up a little momentum, maybe even get a rush — “hey, I’ve really gotten good at this” — before hitting the halfway point or so and falling flat on my face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: No. 2 Climate Diplomat to Leave Post
description: Jonathan Pershing, a veteran diplomat, worked to reassert the U.S. role in global negotiations. He said he was optimistic that the world will avert climate catastrophe.
content: WASHINGTON — Jonathan Pershing, who traveled to 21 countries to negotiate an international climate agreement last year as the Biden administration’s No. 2 global climate envoy, is leaving his position next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Vegan Travel: It’s Not Fringe Anymore
description: From Mexico to Greece, plant-centric hotels, restaurants and tours are proliferating.
content: When she went vegan about four years ago, Colleen Corbett, a bartender based in Tampa, Fla., thought she might starve or be forced to eat meat when traveling abroad. Instead, it was just the beginning of her explorations of the burgeoning vegan destinations that have flourished around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Mourinho, Benítez and the Pursuit of the Past
description: Why do two elite managers persist with a trophy-less, and seemingly joyless, slog toward a past they probably will never reclaim?
content: In the sudden flood of spare time he had after departing Manchester United, José Mourinho filmed a commercial for a bookmaker. A couple of years and a couple of jobs on, it is still running on British television. It still works, after all. Mourinho is still a household name in Britain. The ad’s central concept holds up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: An Ocean May Lurk Inside Saturn’s ‘Death Star’ Moon
description: New research is converting some skeptics to the idea that tiny, icy Mimas may be full of liquid.
content: That’s a moon … and a waterlogged ice ball?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: In ‘Whisper House,’ the Living Are the Pawns of the Dead
description: A lighthouse keeper, the nephew living with her and a Japanese employee are on alert for U-boats and graver threats in this chamber musical set in 1942.
content: The ghosts, at least, are having fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below, along with some solving tips and tricks by Wordplay’s own Deb Amlen.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Love Letter: An Emotionally Absent Mother of the Bride
description: And: A couple overcomes loss together.
content: There’s something about weddings that tends to stir up unresolved family issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall, Ben Sisario and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Meat Loaf, ‘Bat Out of Hell’ Singer and Actor, Dies at 74
description: Born Marvin Lee Aday, he sold millions of albums, won a Grammy and acted in films including “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” and “Fight Club.”
content: Meat Loaf, the larger-than-life rocker whose 1977 debut, “Bat Out of Hell” — a campy amalgam of hard rock and Broadway-style bombast — became one of the best-selling albums of all time, died on Thursday. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: N.C.A.A. Reorganizes Around New Constitution That Shifts Power to Universities
description: The organizing body in college sports also adopted new rules for transgender athletes to mirror other elite sports in the United States.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — N.C.A.A. member schools and conferences voted Thursday to adopt a new, stripped-down constitution, the first step in decentralizing an organization that faces increasing challenges to its relevancy as the chief authority in college sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: What Biden’s Chief of Staff Has Learned, One Year In
description: Ron Klain reflects on the first year of the administration.
content: It’s been a year since Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th president of the United States. And what a roller coaster of a year it’s been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: A Reimagined ‘Long Day’s Journey Into Night’ for the Covid Era
description: Robert O’Hara directs a trimmed-down revival of Eugene O’Neill’s classic, with a colorblind cast and a weary eye on the pandemic and the opioid crisis.
content: Of the time-honored classics of American theater, Eugene O’Neill’s “Long Day’s Journey Into Night” is one that usually takes its own concept of time seriously. A four-act work based on the playwright’s own dysfunctional parents, it follows the disintegration of the Tyrone family — by disease, ego, addiction and codependency — through the course of a claustrophobic August day at their seaside home in Connecticut. Widely considered O’Neill’s masterpiece, it typically runs just under four hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Readers Have Questions About Stocks. An Economist Replies.
description: The economist Laurence Kotlikoff responds to questions from Times readers.
content: Lots of readers responded to my Jan. 5 newsletter discussing a new book, “Money Magic: An Economist’s Secrets to More Money, Less Risk, and a Better Life,” by the Boston University economist Laurence Kotlikoff. I’ve already responded to many of you by email but nothing beats hearing from Kotlikoff himself. I presented him with some of your questions and criticisms, and he replied. Here’s that exchange:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bob Goalby, Masters Champion Thanks to a Gaffe, Dies at 92
description: He won at Augusta in 1968 after Robert De Vincenzo signed an incorrect scorecard. But to many, the victory was tainted, leaving Goalby feeling like the victim.
content: Bob Goalby, the 1968 Masters champion whose victory was shadowed by one of golf’s most memorable gaffes, Roberto De Vicenzo’s signing of an incorrect scorecard, died on Thursday in Belleville, Ill. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Louie Anderson and the Compassion of America’s Eternal Kid
description: He displayed an empathetic humanity that he shared offstage with his friend Bob Saget. The loss of both comics represents the end of an era.
content: One of the first killer jokes in the stand-up act of Louie Anderson was about the meanness of older brothers. Imitating one of his own in an intimidating voice, he warned that there was a monster in a swamp nearby. With childlike fear in his eyes, Anderson reported that he avoided that area “until I got a little older and a little smarter and a little brother.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Peloton considers layoffs but denies a report it will pause bike production.
description: The company has faced an abrupt change in fortune over the past year, from complaints that it couldn’t deliver bikes on time, to a drop in demand as gyms reopened and pandemic restrictions were lifted.
content: Peloton, the maker of stationary bikes and livestreamed workouts that enjoyed a surge in demand as gyms shut down during the pandemic, is considering laying off some workers and making changes to its production as the once-hot interest in its products slows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Lybarger
title: Overlooked No More: Lee Godie, Eccentric Chicago Street Artist
description: A self-described Impressionist, she hawked her art on Michigan Avenue in the 1970s and ’80s and lived mostly outdoors. But her work is in museums.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Racial Turmoil Mars Signs of Progress at the U.S. Mint
description: A new internal report found that Black employees felt marginalized at the Treasury agency that produces the nation’s coins.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States Mint celebrated a milestone this month when it announced the first shipment of a new batch of quarters bearing the image of the writer and poet Maya Angelou, the first Black woman to be depicted on the 25-cent coin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eyal Press
title: In Medicine, a Lack of Courage Has Helped Put Roe in Jeopardy
description: Stigma and fear of harassment have kept physicians from incorporating abortion into their practice.
content: This Saturday marks the 49th, and quite possibly the last, anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion in every state. Roe’s precarious future can be attributed to various factors: the tenacity of the anti-abortion movement, the addition of three conservative justices to the court during Donald Trump’s presidency, the opportunities that pro-choice advocates may have missed. But if, as is widely expected, the Supreme Court upholds a Mississippi statute that bans most abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy and overturns or guts Roe later this year, I will be thinking about something else: not the legal precedent, but the role that lawlessness and terrorism — and the medical community’s response to it — played in hastening Roe’s demise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 6 Premiere Recap: Fire in the Hole
description: Chuck goes to war with a billionaire, but probably not the one audiences expected. Prince tries his best to be different from his predecessor.
content: The Season 6 premiere of “Billions” was given a surprise early release on Friday morning, available free across multiple streaming platforms, including Showtime.com and YouTube. Future recaps will publish after episodes air on Sunday nights.

title: Igor Fruman, Former Giuliani Associate, Is Sentenced to One Year in Prison
description: Mr. Fruman was at the center of a campaign to damage then-President Donald J. Trump’s rivals, but was brought down by campaign finance charges.
content: Well before the 2020 presidential election, when he was an associate of Rudolph W. Giuliani, Igor Fruman was on the front lines of a shadowy diplomacy campaign to advance then-President Donald J. Trump’s interests and damage his political adversaries.

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: It’s a TV bumper crop.
content: Welcome. It’s peak season for indoor cats, for tea-sippers and soup-stirrers and, most crucially, for binge-watchers. After a couple of relatively lean years on the streaming circuit, it feels, finally, like a moment of abundance. We’re awash in stuff to watch, old and new.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Pete Davidson and Colin Jost Just Bought a Staten Island Ferry

content: For about 24 hours, it was a New York City mystery: Who would pay more than $280,000 for a hulking, orange 57-year-old Staten Island Ferry boat whose engines don’t work?

author: By Michael Crowley and Anton Troianovski
title: U.S. and Russia Take More Measured Stance in Ukraine Talks
description: The conciliatory tone and absence of ultimatums suggested that both sides were trying to keep tensions in check and give diplomacy time.
content: GENEVA — The United States and Russia scaled back their confrontational rhetoric over Eastern European security on Friday, agreeing to extend negotiations as the Biden administration pursues a fragile diplomatic path to averting a Russian invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 Panel and State Officials Seek Answers on Fake Trump Electors
description: Pressure is mounting on the Justice Department to investigate bogus electors who claimed that Donald J. Trump defeated Joseph R. Biden Jr. in their states.
content: WASHINGTON — Law enforcement officials, members of Congress and the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol are digging deeper into the role that fake slates of electors played in efforts by former President Donald J. Trump to cling to power after he lost the 2020 election.

content: THE FIFTIESAn Underground HistoryBy James R. Gaines

author: By Michael Astor
title: Elza Soares, 91, Who Pushed the Boundaries of Brazilian Music, Dies
description: She rose from a favela in Rio to samba stardom in the 1960s. But her career was later overshadowed by an affair with a famous soccer player that became a national scandal.
content: Elza Soares, the samba singer whose meteoric rise from the favela to stardom was later eclipsed by a scandalous affair with one of Brazil’s most famous soccer stars, died on Thursday at her home in Rio de Janeiro. She was 91.

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: Three Restorative Recipes to Warm From Within
description: An uplifting tonic, a renewing broth and an enlivening soup are just a few ways Yewande Komolafe makes it through the season.
content: Like a lot of people who’ve moved to New York from warmer climates, I always find it takes me some time to adjust — both physically and mentally — to New York winters. When I feel the kitchen floor getting cold in the mornings or the draft seeping in from the windows, I know it’s time to start modifying my meals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: Do Men Still Rule Ballet? Let Us Count the Ways.
description: Elizabeth B. Yntema’s Dance Data Project has been using a steady drumbeat of numbers to push the ballet world to action on gender equality.
content: Periodically, arts writers and critics will sound the alarm: Ballet has a significant gender gap. Women fill ballet’s stages and classrooms, but choreographers and artistic directors — the people with power — are predominantly men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Zero-Covid Policy Shakes Hong Kong’s Economy and Its ‘Soul’
description: Businesses that held on through several outbreaks are now trembling as the highflying metropolitan hub struggles with supply chain issues and a relentless approach to the pandemic.
content: HONG KONG — Perry Lam felt confident that his business had weathered the worst of the pandemic. Several rounds of bar closures in Hong Kong had dimmed the city’s vibrant nightlife, threatening to destroy his brewery. But things seemed better late last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Winners of Our 3rd Annual Personal Narrative Essay Contest for Students
description: Eight short, powerful essays from teenagers about the moments, big and small, that have shaped them.
content: For a third year, we invited students from 11 to 19 to tell us short, powerful stories about a meaningful life experience for our Personal Narrative Writing Contest. And for a third year, we heard from young people across the globe about the moments, big and small, that have shaped them into who they are today: a first kiss that failed to meet expectations, a school assignment that led to self-acceptance, an incident at airport security that made the world look much less sweet, and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Damien Hirst and the Art of the Deal
description: He might be Britain’s richest artist, but with each attempt to monetize his talent, Hirst’s originality as a conceptual sculptor becomes an ever more distant memory.
content: LONDON — “He’s a talented artist, but this? Really?” said Alan Baldwin, an art collector, looking down recently at a fluffy black sculpture of a spider with bow legs and googly eyes. Back in 1992, three years before winning the prestigious Turner Prize, its creator had astounded the art world by displaying a real 14-foot tiger shark embalmed in a tank of formaldehyde.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A First Payday for a Mayor, and for Cryptocurrency
description: Mayor Eric Adams wants New York City to become the global capital for cryptocurrency.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at what Mayor Eric Adams plans to do with his first paycheck. We’ll also look at a new study of how New York City could become more technology-oriented, which recommends testing drones to inspect buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Biden Versus the Friends of Covid
description: Anti-vaccine politics explain many of the president’s problems.
content: President Biden ended his first year in office on a low note, with polls showing public disapproval of his handling of, well, just about everything. We are, of course, hearing endless commentary about his political missteps, along with some acknowledgment that public expectations were too high given the razor-thin Democratic majority in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Annie Karni
title: ‘I Will Not Sit Quietly’: 3 Black Senators in Spotlight on Voting Rights
description: Senators Cory Booker, Tim Scott and Raphael Warnock brought vastly different perspectives to proceedings that highlighted the Senate’s striking lack of diversity.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate has only three Black members, a paltry number that is unrepresentative of the country, so when the chamber took up a voting rights bill this week aimed at preventing the disenfranchisement of voters of color, Senators Cory Booker, Tim Scott and Raphael Warnock played an outsized role in the debate.

title: After Being Stuck in Russia, a Director Touches Down in Germany
description: Kirill Serebrennikov is living under a three-year travel ban, but to his surprise, Russian authorities approved his request to direct a play in Hamburg.
content: HAMBURG, Germany — At first glance, a recent rehearsal at the Thalia Theater here looked much like any other. Onstage, the actors ran through the final scene of a play called “The Black Monk,” trying to get the flow just right.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Knockout Country-Rap Crossover, and 13 More New Songs

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Miller
title: Social Security offices, closed in the pandemic, are expected to reopen in March.
description: The agency, whose offices were closed nearly two years ago, and the unions representing its work force agreed to reopen more than 1,200 offices.
content: The national network of Social Security customer service offices, which were closed nearly two years ago at the start of the pandemic, is on track to reopen on March 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Jacobs
title: The Most Exciting Sporting Event in the World Is Happening Right Now
description: The Africa Cup of Nations soccer tournament shows glimpses of a different vision for the continent.
content: In March 1957, Ghana cast off British colonialism and became the first country in sub-Saharan Africa to achieve political self-rule. At its independence celebrations, the new prime minister, Kwame Nkrumah, offered a hopeful message: “We are going to create our own African personality and identity. It is the only way we can show the world that we are ready for our own battles.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: As China holds the line on ‘zero Covid,’ some wonder if that’s sustainable.
description: China has largely kept the coronavirus at bay since 2020, but officials there are going to ever more extreme lengths to quell outbreaks that have proliferated around the country in recent weeks.
content: China has largely kept the coronavirus at bay since 2020, but officials there are going to ever more extreme lengths to quell outbreaks that have proliferated around the country in recent weeks.

author: By Damien Cave
title: Heard, Felt but Barely Seen: How a Volcano Severed Tonga From the World
description: The disaster caused by the largest eruption in decades has been defined so far by the nation’s near-complete disconnection in an ever-connected age.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — When the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha’apai volcano erupted with colossal force at 5:10 p.m. local time on Saturday, Jan. 15, Soane Francis Siua, a Catholic seminary student in Fiji, heard a loud boom and tried to work out why the earth seemed to be rattling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: So You Think You’re a Covid Expert (but Are You?)
description: How long should you isolate? What tests are the most reliable? Do vaccine cocktails work? Some people have turned into amateur scientists as they look for answers.
content: Lauren Terry, 23, thought she would know what to do if she contracted Covid-19. After all, she manages  a lab in Tucson that processes Covid tests.

title: As Omicron Crests, Booster Shots Are Keeping Americans Out of Hospitals

content: Booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are not just reducing the number of infections with the highly contagious Omicron variant, they’re also keeping infected Americans out of hospitals, according to data published on Friday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Mental Health Toll of Trump-Era Politics
description: When politics becomes “a pervasive and largely unavoidable source of chronic stress.”
content: In the last few years the hideous state of our politics has often kept me up at night, but until recently I thought I was an outlier. Even when I’ve written about political despair as a problem for Democrats, I assumed it was something that applied to activists and base voters, the sort of people who go through their days silently cursing Joe Manchin. But a striking new study from Kevin B. Smith, chair of the political science department at the University of Nebraska, Lincoln, suggests the universe of people who find our politics a torment might be much larger than I’d realized.
source.name: The New York Times

For help answering them, I called on two of the leading experts on mindfulness and habits. Dr. Judson Brewer is the director of research and innovation at the Brown University Mindfulness Center and the creator of the Eat Right Now app. Evan Forman is a psychology professor at Drexel University in Philadelphia and the director of the university’s Center for Weight, Eating and Lifestyle Science.

content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Fighters from the Islamic State attacked a prison in northeast Syria in an attempt to free thousands of their comrades, one of the boldest assaults by the terrorist group in the Middle East since the fall of its so-called caliphate three years ago, U.S. and Kurdish officials said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecile Richards
title: The One Regret From My Time Leading Planned Parenthood
description: The erosion of reproductive rights is a result of raw, bare-knuckled politics, as a minority exercises its power over a majority.
content: This could well be the last anniversary of Roe. Ever since the Supreme Court established a constitutional right to abortion through that decision, 49 years ago on Saturday, Republicans have been chipping away at reproductive rights. Now, the court is poised to overturn the decision once and for all — fulfilling a longstanding dream not just of fringe elements of the Republican Party, but also of its leadership. I know, because I was one of the leading faces of the movement trying to stop them.
